content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms. The Act, known as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017," defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, and foreign air carrier. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to airport security, including "intelligence community," "secured area," "Security Identification Display Area," and "sterile area." The curr_chunk focuses on the requirement for a cost and feasibility study. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study on implementing security measures at various airports, including secure doors, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies. The study required under subsection (a) will include information on employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening of employees accessing secured areas. This includes costs of establishing entry and exit points and comparing costs and effectiveness of security features to the Federal Government. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess the quality and reliability of the study required under subsection (a) regarding employee screening costs at airports. The assessment report will be submitted to relevant committees within 60 days of receiving the study. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be assessed to ensure security practices are in place. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards and require social security numbers for SIDA applications to strengthen security vetting effectiveness. A report on the assessment results will be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days. The Administrator will issue requirements for airport operators to inform applicants that employees with access to a Security Identification Display Area may be screened at any time. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. Furthermore, within the same timeframe, the Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to utilize resources from the Department of Homeland Security for insider threat education and mitigation. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators. Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic to enhance security effectiveness. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators. Recommendations and technical assistance will be given to air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators for conducting their own employee inspections. Additionally, the Administrator will submit annual reports on the frequency, methodology, strategy, and effectiveness of employee inspection operations at airports for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. A centralized database will be established within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Administrator, in consultation with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges for security non-compliance. Reporting mechanisms for air carriers and airport operators to submit data and access the database will be determined. A process will be set up for individuals to correct mistaken entries in the database. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other relevant entities. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of IT security controls within 90 days. No additional funds are authorized. SEC. 8. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. The requirements of this Act will be carried out using existing authorized amounts.
